text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ... Mrs. Emma E. McVoy
Address ... Duncan, Sask.
Birthplace ... Mound City, but we lived 25 miles northwes

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ... 1908
Where did you set up housekeeping? ... First at my parents' home then in 1908
Where had you been living before that? ... North of Mound City, State of CRAIK
For how many people did you prepare meals? ... Varied from 4 to 12
How far was it to your nearest store? ... Six miles ... TR. CRAIK
How often could a visit be made to the store? ... Once or twice a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
My parents were real pioneers as they came to Moose Jaw in the 1880s; my mother in 1885 and Dad a couple of years later. They were married at Moose Jaw.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ... Hardin's Hard
In what quantities did you buy it? ... From 200 to 400 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ... $1.50
How much did you use graham flour? ... None
Whole wheat flour? ... None
Was flour milled locally? ... Yes, a mill at Kinsmen
How far away? ... 30 miles
What year? ... 1922
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ... Can't Remember
What other grain products did you use? ... None
Cormeal? ... Yes
Whole Wheat? ... None
Farina? ... None
Other? ... Granulated oatmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ... Sometimes
How did you grind it? ... With a small coffee mill

In the year 1900 and before butter was packed in wooden tubs about the shape of a water pail. They were called ferkins and were of hardwood. There was three sizes: the small would hold 20 pounds of butter, next 40 pounds and large 60 pounds.
1905 (last date)

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Miss Anna McIlvain

Address: [illegible]

Birthplace: [illegible]

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Saskatchewan? [illegible]

Where had you been living before that? [illegible]

For how many years did you live there? [illegible]

How far was it to your nearest store? [illegible]

How often could a visit be made to the store? [illegible]

What groceries did you usually buy in those early years? [illegible]

My parents were real pioneers as they came to Canada in 1880 and lived in [illegible] for many years.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? [illegible]

In what quantities did you buy it? [illegible]

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? [illegible]

How much did you use graham flour? [illegible]

Was flour milled locally? [illegible]

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? [illegible]

What other grain products did you use? [illegible]

Other? [illegible]

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? [illegible]

How did you grind it? [illegible]

In spring 1900 and fall, butter was packed in wooden tubs about the shape of a water pail. These were called "pails" and were of hardwood. There was three days. The small would hold 20 pounds of butter next 40 pounds and large 60.
The ranchers milked about 6 to 10 cows so they made a lot of butter.

No separators then, set milk in pans in a cool place called milkhouse after the milk set 24 hours the cream was skimmed off with a tin skimmer about the size and shape of a saucer it had tiny holes in it to let the milk through but the cream being thicker it did not go through. A person had to do it fast putting the cream into a big crock. Then in a few days it had to be churned.

It sure looked good in nice big lumps the size of oranges and nearly the same color. After washing in a butter wooden bowl with wooden ladle with several changes of good cold water it was salted mixed hourly and packed in a ferkin when the ferkin was full a piece of white cloth called buttercloth was dipped in cold salty water then spread over the top off butter then the wooden lid put on tight. Some people kept their butter 2 to 3 months before taking to stores when sold the storekeeper would let you have empty ferkins to replace the full ones and you would start all over again. I like Dairy butter much better than Creamery butter.
The ranchers milked about 6 to 10 cows.

No refrigerators then. Let milk in pans in a cool place called "milkhouse" after the milk set 24 hours. The cream was skimmed off with a tin skimmer about the size and shape of a dinner plate. It had tiny holes in top to let the milk through but the cream being thicker did not go through. A person held a big crack them in a few days it had to be churned. Looked good on rich pig farms. The size of pans used and nearly wooden casks after washing in a salt water bath with wood lathes several mixed thoroughly and sealed in a pail when the milk was full a piece of white cloth called butter cloth was dipped in cold salt water then spread over the top of butter then the wooden lid put on tight. Done people kept their butter 2 to 3 months before taking to stores when sold the storekeeper would cut you have empty looking to replace his old ones and you would start all over again. I think pure milk's much better than Creamery butter!
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...in about 20 lbs. in paper bags.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...50 cents.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Honey Drips and Crown brand.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...16 oz.
At what price? ...95 cents per can.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...by milking cows.
Butter? ...made our own.
Eggs? ...had hens to lay brown eggs.
What was the price of butter? ...about 15 cents per lb.
Did you pack eggs for winter? ...yes.
Did you make butter? ...yes. Churned it into cheese.
What kind of cheese? ...it was a plain white cheese. Very good.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...beef during cool weather.
Pork cured in salt brine or a barrel in summer.
How did you get fresh meat? ...shot ducks. Had our own chickens.
Sometimes had fish. Fish in winter from Long Lake.
How often did you get fresh meat? ...twice a week in summer.
How did you preserve meat? ...by keeping in salt brine.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...no.
If so what year was it organized? ...don't know.
Did you use game? ...yes. Sometimes. What kinds? ...Prairie chicken and Wild Ducks.
For how long? ...not sure.
What part did fish play in the family diet? ...very little.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...fresh.
Kinds? ...suckers, White fish, and Jack fish.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ... 50 cents.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ... 50 cents.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ... Honey Maid and Golden Maid.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ... 1 lb.

At what price? ... 95 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ... By milking cows.

Did you own cows? ... Yes.

What was the price of butter? ... 16 cents per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? ... Yes.

Did you make butter? ... Yes.

What kind of cheese? ... White.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... Beef, mutton, and pork.

How did you get fresh meat? ... From our own chickens.

How often did you get fresh meat? ... Twice a week.

How did you preserve meat? ... By smoking in salted brine.

Was there a "beer ring" in your neighborhood? ... No.

If so what year was it organized? ... 1870.

Did you use game? ... Yes.

For how long? ... 20 years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... Very little.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Fresh.

Kind? ... Whitefish and smelt.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Black, Red, Green, etc. At what price? $1.00.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Both.

Price? About 20 cents. What other beverages were used? Cocoa.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $1.00.

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: Every year.

Potatoes, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Both ways.

What was the price of prunes? About 10 cents per lb.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

peas? No., corn? No., beans? No., Saskatoons? Yes.

other foods? Yes.

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1912.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1929.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar?

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) 
Price?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cakes...very cheap
Did you make yeast for your own use? No...Using starter? Yes...
Using hops? No...Salt rising? No...
Did you buy baking powder? Yes...Baking soda? Yes...
Cream of tartar? Yes...Cheap...Did you make your own baking powder? No...

Using hops? Salt rising?

Did you make your own baking powder? No
Cream of tartar? Yes... Chalk... Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slop, dugout) ... well ...

How far was this water from your home? ... right next ...

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... hand ...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. ...
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ...bought...wood ashes?
If you made your own, did you use lye? ...yes...
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ...Royal Crown...

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ...wood...
Where did you get your fuel? ...N.W. Rue, Apple Valley...
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Started using coal in 1904.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...no...
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? No (Give dates) .............
By whom was your first cook stove made? ...McClay...
What year was it purchased? ...1876...Price? $20.00...
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) .........stroke means yes
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ............
When did you first see enamel ware? ...1900...
Aluminum? ...1910...
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ... Bought little.

If you made your own, did you use lye? ... Yes, about 1920.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ... Regular cream.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ... Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? ... From the Adirondacks.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. ... Started using coal in 1904.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ... No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or take over? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? ... Mrs. Clapp.

What year was it purchased? ... Years before 1874.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? ... 1902.

Aluminum? ... 1910.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Break.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - Porridge, Toast, Eggs, Syrup, Jam, Tea with Cream, Milk, Pancakes often.

Dinner - Potatoes, Bread and Butter, Meat, Pudding or Pie, either Raisin, Rhubarb, Apple or Custard.

Supper - Potatoes, Meat or Eggs, Bread and Butter, Cake, Fruit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ....... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Roast Chickens, Vegetables, Plum pudding (really suit pudding with raisins in it), Cranberry Sauce, Fancy Cakes - Christmas Cake.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
16. WAREHOUSES AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the warehouses and containers received with the food you purchased at the dates shown possible.

Break

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - Porridge, Toast, Pancakes of Grain, Tea with Cream, Milk, Pancakes of Grain

Dinner - Potatoes, Bread and Butter, Meat, Pudding or Pie, Other Ration (Churned, Apple or Celery)

Supper - Potatoes, Meat, Eggs, Bread and Butter

Fruit

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ..........

Roast Chicken, Vegetables

Plum Pudding (really suet pudding with raisins in it), Cranberry Sauce

Ramey Cakes - Christmas Cake

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level? Living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Everybody made their own bread in the early days, but the past 20 years a lot of people buy their bread. One could not do that back in 1904. Married women baked bread for bachelors and only charged 10 cents per loaf.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the excellent days as compared with today.

Every body made their own bread in the early days. But the last 20 years a lot of people buy thin bread. One could not do that back in 1904. Married women baked bread for themselves and only charged 10 cents per loaf.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and homemade prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing food. All other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada, include items not mentioned above, quality methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortage and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
